awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  A Novel Probe for Biofilms
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project will be to improve performance of pulp and paper mills, especially small mills in rural areas, and to improve the quality of their products.  The main components of wood are cellulose (used for paper), hemicellulose, and lignin (which makes paper turn yellow and brittle with age).  Removal of lignin is key to papermaking, but it is typically attached to the hemicellulose.  The project advances a technology to measure how much lignin is left in wood pulp.  In the longer term, the probe may also detect biofilms which are layers of carbohydrates and other materials in which bacteria and fungi can grow.  Water treatment facilities and processors of plant-derived materials routinely find that microorganisms naturally present in their starting materials form biofilms that can accumulate on machinery or contaminate the products. This technology has wide-ranging applications.  

The proposed project creates a peptide probe for non-glycosidic bonds to xylose residues of oligo- or polysaccharides.  These bonds are known to exist in wood, and may exist in other woody plants and biofilms.  The project employs the only enzyme known to break these bonds, XLE (xylan:lignin etherase) in order to create a peptide probe to indicate their presence.  XLE’s homology to known xylosidases has permitted the identification of residues very likely to participate in the catalytic activity.  These residues will be targets of modification that remove catalytic activity while retaining the ability to bind to XLE’s non-glycosidic substrate.  The modifications will be performed using standard techniques of molecular biology and evaluated using with a novel indicating substrate for XLE activity.  XLE’s homology with known glycosidases has also allowed identification of the enzyme’s potential binding site for its substrate.  A peptide with an attached visible marker corresponding to this sequence but including the sequence changes that remove the catalytic activity will be synthesized.  The resulting peptide will be tested to see if it reacts with wood pulp and biofilms.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Tethys Research LLC developed two novel enzymes that recognize unusual bonds between polysaccharides (chains of sugars) and lignin.  Polysaccharides are major components of wood and are converted into paper by pulp and paper mills. Lignin is the substance in wood and higher plants that, if not removed during manufacturing, causes paper to become yellow and brittle over time. Tethys hypothesizes that biofilms contain some of the same chemical structures as the bonds between polysaccharides and lignin in wood and higher plants. This NSF project was designed to show that peptides (pieces of proteins) from these proprietary enzymes could be used to produce a probe that reveals the presence of biofilms. 
     Development of such a probe has high commercial value. Industrial processors of raw biomaterials need to detect and cost-effectively clean their manufacturing equipment and pipes, which get coated with biofilms produced by microorganisms naturally present in the raw materials. The build-up of biofilms narrows tolerances, changes frictional interactions between equipment and biomaterials, and contaminates the final product with microbes shed by the biofilm communities. Current strategies to remove biofilms rely on physical cleaning, which in turn requires regular costly shutdowns of the processing line.
     The medical device market faces a similar problem with biofilm contami-nation, particularly in-dwelling catheters, as biofilms provide a good envir-onment for bacterial and fungal growth while increasing recalcitrance to antibiotics. It is estimated that about 80% of both bacterial and non-bacterial microbial infections of in-dwelling catheters are associated with biofilms. Proactive monitoring of in-dwelling catheters would prevent serious and costly patient infections.
     In addition to biofilm detection, Tethys hypothesizes that the peptides developed in this project can also be the basis for a quick and cost-effective kappa number test for the pulp and paper industry. The kappa test many mills currently use was developed in the 19th century. It measures the remaining lignin in the pulp and paper making process and requires several hours of work by a chemist on the multiple samples taken from various points along the processing line. Current alternatives to the kappa number test are extremely expensive to install and require constant monitoring by trained engineering personnel. The final test envisioned by this research and initiated in this grant would require no chemistry background, no engineering into the processing line, and finish in less than 15 minutes. The new kappa test would be less expensive than either the older kappa measurement or the newer automated monitoring.
     The project outcome was the development of a novel peptide, which was successfully tested and shown to bind to the type of bonds existing between polysaccharides and lignin.  Unfortunately, the project was truncated prematurely due to the serious illness of the Principal Investigator. The remaining work to demonstrate binding of the peptide to biofilms in situ remains but can be accomplished expeditiously by a commercial partner. The scientific and biochemical engineering work required to develop the peptide into a replacement for the kappa number test is straightforward and is being discussed with potential partners.
​
